abstract.p: Sally Marsh, casting agent, loves Roberto Cavalli fashions of 1970's, which are making a comeback; photo (S)

block.p: When Roberto Cavalli's designs were popular in the 1970's, Sally Marsh did not wear them, but she isn't missing the chance now that they have made a comeback. Passing the Roberto Cavalli boutique, which opened in September at 711 Madison Avenue (63rd Street), she found that the mannequins in feather-trimmed jeans, metallic print tops and painted leather jackets made her nostalgic for her wilder days in the 70's, when she was a publicist for a London nightclub.
''It was bizarre and glitzy,'' Ms. Marsh, 46, said of the display, which included banners decorated with giant roses sewn out of candy-color paillettes.

''It was bizarre and glitzy,'' Ms. Marsh, 46, said of the display, which included banners decorated with giant roses sewn out of candy-color paillettes.
''The whole store is a fantasy,'' she added.

Now a casting agent for clothing catalogs and a producer of fashion shoots, Ms. Marsh said she and her colleagues have been buying up Cavalli's animal-inspired creations because they like the ''borderline tarty'' look.

Not long ago, she wore the ensemble on the left -- gold stretch jeans printed to look like wolf fur (on sale for $234) and a matching velvet cardigan with a fox collar (on sale for $492) -- to a black-tie affair.
She could hardly say she fitted in with the elegant crowd, Ms. Marsh remarked, ''But everyone thought it was really fun.''
